Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Ecological Costs and Benefits of Secondary Compounds in Fleshy Fruits
Award.AbstractNarration:
Because plants are rooted in place, their ability to colonize new areas often depends on animals, who consume fruits, move elsewhere, and then deposit the seeds contained in those fruits. This form of seed dispersal is essential for the natural regeneration of forests. To attract seed dispersers, plants produce nutritious and colorful fruits; however, the nutrients in those fruits can also attract fruit pests, such as insects and fungi that cause fruits to rot. As a defense against such enemies, plants produce an array of chemical compounds, called natural products or secondary compounds, that can act as insecticides or fungicides. These compounds are often used by humans as organic pesticides or in the treatment of infections, but very little is known about the variety of compounds produced in fruits and how they affect the animals that depend on fruits for food. This research will examine a group of these fruit natural products, the amide-alkaloids, that are found in tropical pepper plants (family Piperaceae), a large group that includes several economically important species (such as Piper nigrum, the fruits of which are the source of black pepper). A series of experiments will test the effects of individual amide-alkaloids on the organisms that consume pepper fruits in tropical forests. These organisms include fruit-feeding bats, which are the main beneficial seed dispersers of pepper fruits, as well as fruit pests such as insects and fungi. All field experiments will be conducted at the La Selva Biological Station in Costa Rica, an area where pepper plants and their associated fruit-feeding bats, insect pests and fungi are found in high abundance.

The benefits of the study include an improved understanding of seed dispersal and the natural defense of fruits against pests -- two processes that are critical for plant survival and have direct relevance for agriculture and forest management. In addition, this study will create excellent opportunities for undergraduate and graduate student training due to its integrative approach that combines biology and chemistry. The research team will include students from both the US and Costa Rica, providing opportunities for international collaboration and cultural exchange. The results will be disseminated through scientific publications, as well as educational activities for K-12 students and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Because plants are rooted in place, their ability to colonize new areas often depends on animals, who consume fruits and then inadvertently disperse seeds to new sites. To attract animal dispersers, plants have evolved nutritious and attractive fruits; however, many fruits also contain a variety of chemical compounds, called natural products or secondary metabolites, that can be deterrent or in some cases highly toxic to consumers. These compounds are often used by humans as organic pesticides or in the treatment of infections, but very little is known about the variety of compounds produced in fruits, the evolutionary reasons for their occurrence, and how they affect the animals that depend on fruits for food.  This research examined a group of these fruit natural products, the amide-alkaloids, which are found in tropical pepper plants (the genus Piper). These are the compounds responsible for the spicy heat of black peppercorns, which are the dried fruits of Piper nigrum. They have known medicinal properties and bioactivity against a number of pathogens or human-associated pests, but virtually nothing is known about their ecological significance in wild fruits.  We conducted the first chemical analyses of amide-alkaloids in Piper reticulatum, a common and abundant species in the rainforest understory throughout the neotropics, and described over 30 individual compounds that occur in its fruits and seeds. A series of experiments then tested the effects of amide-alkaloids on the organisms that consume pepper fruits in tropical forests.  These organisms included fruit-feeding bats, which are the main beneficial seed dispersers of pepper fruits, as well as fruit pests such as insects and fungi.  All field experiments were conducted at La Selva Biological Station in Costa Rica, an area where pepper plants and their associated fruit-feeding bats, insect pests and fungi are found in high abundance. The complete study resulted in three main findings: 1) fruits and seeds contain high concentrations and diverse mixtures of amide-alkaloids relative to other plant parts, 2) the amide-alkaloids produced in fruits can function to defend plants against insect pests and fungal pathogens, and 3) the same compounds can also deter beneficial fruit-feeding bats. This suggests that the amide-alkaloids in fruits represent a trade-off between attracting seed dispersers and defending fruits against pests.

The study has provided an improved scientific understanding of seed dispersal and the natural defense of fruits against pests, two processes that are critical for plant survival and forest regeneration. Four papers related to the project were published or are in press in peer-reviewed scientific journals, and results were presented at three scientific conferences over the course of the award period. The integrative approach of the project, involving detailed chemical analyses and field experiments with plants, bats, insects, and fungi, provided excellent training opportunities for the graduate student co-PI (Whitehead) as well as 11 undergraduate students that were involved in the project as field or lab assistants. The research team included students from the US as well as 3 Costa Rican students (one of whom was an integral part of the bat experiments and will be co-author on one of the published papers), which provided excellent opportunities for international collaboration and cultural exchange. The project was also featured in a number of educational activities developed by the PI and co-PI for K-12 students and implemented through two existing University of Colorado outreach programs, Science Discovery and the GAMES (Girls at the Museum Enjoying Science) program at the Museum of Natural History in Boulder, CO.
